It had been towed in there because it certainly didn't seem to be a Newport ship as such.
It was right in the middle of the Walls of the Roses.
And at that time the man we all call Warwick the Kingmaker had actually succeeded in capturing Newport
as part of territories of the then Earl or the late Earl of Pembrokes, as he soon became, mooting his head.

a ship to Newport at that time, and other people were paid to repair the ship at Newport.

So with a lot of arguing, it didn't prove anything, according to some, but I think the experts as a whole realised
there was nothing else they could compare it to.
So I'm pretty certain, you can never say never, but 99.9% certain that the references were relating to Newport ships.

Because when the Newport ship was excavated, where the struts supporting the ship were, beneath that they found a skeleton, a headless skeleton.
And immediately people were talking about it being sacrifices and everything else.
But it predated the ship, in fact turned out to be iron age, or everything seems to be iron age.
And the people who were writing the report were talking about it being headless because of the head was sacrificed separately.
Well they didn't have Derek Upton's experience, nor him talking with the police, which I listened to.
And all the time you find bodies of people which have drowned in the usk or in the cell, happens frequently.
I can come in to some nice gruesome stories now.
But anyway, basically what tends to happen is somebody either dies or commits suicide or falls overboard, their body floats and it will float up with the tide, which is a massive tide, and then out again.
So it will go in and out.
Now the weakest point in the body is in the neck.
So the necks tend to come away and the heads go off.
So if you then find a headless body alongside the bank, you can assume that it's not necessarily a human sacrifice or anything like that.
There are other things, at least Derek's stories rather than me, because he used to tell them all to me.
There was one case just on the other side, on the Bristol side, but he was trying to cross over at low tide.
And he came across a pair of boots which were upright like this, with human bones sticking in their head.
Someone had got stuck in the mud.
Oh my goodness!
So I then went on to...
I mean that's almost comical but tragic.
I know, yes.
And then I went on, you know, because most people get trapped because of quicksands out there and everything.

The number of parties we've taken out there, they've lost their wellies.
I mean I did it, but then we get blasey about it.
We take the students out there and they're all stuck and we're just sort of walking around because we know how to walk in the mud.
And so they're always coming back covered in mud.
We used to be washed down in the house when we came back because we were so bad.
But I said to Derek, I said, well, did you ever get stuck there?
And he said, oh yes, once I did.
He decided he'd walk out to Denny Island.

So he didn't get that way to Denny Island.
So he started walking back and he got stuck in some mud and he couldn't get out.
So he was lying flat on his face.
So I looked at him and said, well, Derek, why are you still here today then?
He said, well, when the tide came in, it sucks me out.
And I swam in with the tide.
